item.title: JUNE: REGRET
item.content:encoded:
I am currently in Boston on a soul-searching expedition. I don’t know what I’m expecting to find or where exactly I am looking for it. I have plenty of mixed feelings about flying. On the one hand, I am awed by the sheer amount of people going back and forth––to and from “home.” But, on the other hand, I’ve been watching married couples argue over how to make their baby stop crying, people in business who have far too many tabs open for one laptop to run efficiently, and people that almost look like someone I know. But not quite.

I love the feeling of walking along the sidewalk, and everyone else thinking that I’m living a far more exciting life than I am––emulating the life of a writer who is somehow paid a yearly salary, a professor who just got off for summer break, an archaeologist whose dig was canceled. The scariest part of that thought is that I don’t know which image I’m trying to portray. I feel the urge to impress other people––presumably because I assume everyone in the world is somehow in some dystopian optimistic present, when realistically, they are faking it exactly as I am.

I like the idea that I can pack a suitcase and go anywhere in the world, but I do that very infrequently. Why? Well, curiosity and growth are good in theory, but they’re much murkier in practice. 

I talked to an old friend of mine in Cambridge last night, and she told me this story. She babysits on the side, and the kid asked, “What is lightning?” The friend mentioned above is a chemistry major at Harvard, mind you, and they had a vague idea, but not an answer satisfying enough to a child. I thought about the question a bit––it’s some combination of electrons from clouds to the ground. When answering said friend, they replied, “Why would I need to know that? And yeah, I can Google it, but I won’t remember the answer after a minute. It’s not relevant enough in my life.”

I resonated with my friend’s statement, mainly because I’ve been evaluating the virtue of curiosity. I believe it’s essential to keep asking questions, but I also tend to ask a million worlds away. Kant’s phenomenal and noumenal seem to blend. So the question becomes: is it better to continue searching for what feels unknowable, or to focus on what we can reasonably prove?

I have received my housing assignment for the coming year, and I have what seems like a million advising meetings coming up. I learned a bit from my trip––exactly what, yet? I’m unsure. But I loved the feeling of being watched while entirely alone. I wasn’t paranoid that my OCD was impacting anyone besides myself; I could explore at my own pace and be in exactly as many social situations as I desired. And as I enter college, I don’t know that I’ll be able to do it at my own pace, honestly––the decision-making process seems to starts immediately.

I usually panic on a binary scale, which means that most decisions that rely on such a system are my Achilles’ heel. I have relied on being a “jack-of-all-trades” as an excuse for not genuinely excelling at anything. I am passionate about so much that I used it as an excuse to avoid deliberate concentration or improvement. Now that the funnel is continuing, I feel immense pressure to pick one or find a unique way to combine them all. The problem with interdisciplinary work is that there are pretty limited career options to implement all of your degrees. I’m told by hairstylists and Uber drivers that I can always keep some passions as a hobby and continue cultivating them on my own time. Still, I think the problem is that now that I am old enough and in an academic environment to do all of them, I feel motivated to do so. Is completing a double major with a minor impossible? No. But are there unforeseen sacrifices that I would have to make to achieve such a degree? Absolutely. And that is the uncertainty that makes me doubt doing it all.

I want to be integrated without being isolated. In recognition that I feel regretful of some of my prep and lower years at Exeter, I am hoping that I lean into productive mistakes more often.

Course selection enforces a lot of this anxiety. I essentially need to plan when in my time at Duke I can “handle” the most, and that is a balancing act that I haven’t even seen the beginning of yet.

I have started rock climbing, which is something that I could never have envisioned for this year. My body feels tired, but my mind feels like it’s running at a million miles a minute. To be clear––I am an absolute beginner at bouldering, usually only going through V1-V4 routes. I like the feeling of looking at the wall and planning your route, executing on it, and improving for the next run. My climbing partner commented today that I often get halfway up a path, which is usually the most challenging part, then drop down to the mat. I’m not sure if that’s simply because of my limited stamina or strength or if I’m the type of athlete who wants to feel confident in the next move. When I ran, I stopped when it started hurting. I’ve never experienced any runner’s high––I usually feel cramped up and drained afterward. But with climbing, I can pace myself while still feeling plenty sore later. Sure, it’s not cardio, but at least I’m spending more than a few minutes using my body every day.

I’m finding myself embarrassed of the things I say more often. Part of that is meeting new people and talking from the edge; other times, it’s saying things that are hyperbole as a means to be relatable or to not ramble. I don’t trust what I said yesterday, let alone the day before. Half of that is me overthinking my past interactions; most of it is attempting to seem approachable. I often find my statements limited in empathy—assumptions that I make about my experience are usually limited to mine alone. It makes me worry that my generalizations about the world probably tend to be selfish.

I can’t tell how often I lie to myself. Of course, some lies feel larger than others, some feel more like excuses. But, most feel like lies now that I pause and think about it.

In the Midnight Library by Matt Haig, the main character is essentially faced with the Library of Babel filled with her regrets. The problem is that she has already died; regrets upon death seem far more daunting than when alive. The regrets that I have currently have don’t feel pressing enough or don’t feel like they have a good enough trade-off. But I’m trying to live my life as if I am looking at my own Book of Regrets: I should spend less time on social media, I wish my life were more fulfilling, I regret not balancing my life enough. 

So here is to living life, not without regrets, but instead readily aware of them. 

Best,

Alex

item.title: JULY: PERFORMANCE
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I dream of being able to spin a cocoon for myself—not with any man-made tool, but to have been born with a safe haven. I have had a busy few weeks: performing shows with artists in Dallas, finalizing my Duke courses and language placement, a trip to LA, and the capstone will be the songwriting and ancient civilization courses that I am teaching these next few weeks.

I have a lot of faith in strangers. I want to be clear in my distinction of trust as opposed to faith—trust is nurtured, faith is berated until there is none. I would like to have faith that most people are good people, in re: “Strangers.” Innocent until proven guilty.

My anxiety is the largest barrier to my faith, but it is also the largest agent propelling it forward. I am not meant to be around other people. I have come close to perfecting the art of a one-on-one interaction; I’m able to both send and receive cues to make sure that each person is on the same page, and such I feel confident in my ability to socialize. The instant that one-on-one becomes a group of people, I lose my footing—I usually talk more to myself than other people in those instances.

Teaching these classes reminds me why I feel an urge to teach. I feel the same way about the relationship I have with my tutoring students––it’s not about just teaching the right thing, but teaching the right way to approach failure and not understanding. There isn’t much better than being able to relieve someone of confusion. That feeling is more clear in subjects like Latin and Greek where that’s a method to madness, but there’s also a hope in literature analysis of trying to decipher the author’s idea; trying to decipher each other.

I have loved performing these past few weeks. I love the feeling of stepping on a pile of gaff tape, talking to the audience in a more honest rapport than I keep with myself, and playing into the character of the song narrator. I usually go home a bit disappointed, which starts the frenzy of writing an revising all over again. There is an odd instance or two where I feel defeated and dismiss all notions of music for a week or two, but I have some calling towards it. Hell is without a guitar and a notebook. 

I’ve always been keen to record much of my life––a concept which I’m pretty sure I’ve touched on before. But it used to be the relationships I wanted to remember, the group pictures, the odd doodle on scratch paper. Now, I want to remember the perspective. When I feel nostalgia, I don’t think of 5th grade relationships; instead, I remember feeling like the small underdog, battling obstacle after obstacle to finally become a success story. Now I don’t even know what would constitute success. I do feel a bit larger than I did.

I took a trip to Los Angeles to visit a good friend, and the scariest thing to me about the trip were how many adults we met––which led me to bring a mirror to myself. Not too far off from adult after all. Which, did I mention, is the scariest thing anyone could ever tell me? In all sincerity, the world feels so much larger when it is unfamiliar. There was something comforting about adventure; that drive makes me reluctant to sit at home even post travel. 

I am ready to give my all this fall. I want to force honesty upon myself, and the only true way to do that is to face failure as often as possible with it all on the line. I’m starting to make decisions about my four-year plan (which, by the way, I am more than flexible to change. Even when I don’t know what I’m doing with my life, you should believe that I even have the uncertain planned out). I’m not going to decide the person I want to become in college because I know it doesn’t work that way. But I want to be in communities I feel comfortable with and some that I feel like more than a beginner. 

I worry that I’ve forgotten how to stop performing. It sounds cliche that I’m admitting it all feels like an act––I think the person that I am around myself is someone no one else has met. I don’t think there’s any inherent shame that I have towards this person, but I think the narrative is different than I portray it. It’s constantly seeking––if I let it lose, I’d lose my agency.

But if I were to try and describe this person, he would be stern, cynical, and obsessive; trading hopes of the future with fears from the past. I don’t truly believe I can ever fix a mistake, and I think that follows me whether I get away or not. It’s been a pretty constant dialogue recently: reminders of who I think I should be.

I’m hesitant to let that person out because I think he’s far more destructive than I am. I’m not interested in that type of manslaughter: I’m more patient. Mostly because I don’t feel the same type of ambition––I feel ambition as a catalyst, he sees it as survival.

I have just returned from a quick trip that I took to Austin to see a good friend. The trip was quite fun, ranging from boat and golf cart rides to odd family reunions. While immersed in that situation, I felt quite insecure about how I was able to flow with others. I felt off cadence, off topic, off step, which in turn led to further insecurity. I am much better when talking to eight people as opposed to one. That phenomena, I believe, is tied to the performance of it all. In a group of eight, I can tell what my place is, where my comedic timing should be, and what I should be driving in the conversation. The doors feel open, inviting, and almost playful––I can play bits with some in the conversation while peaking the interests of others. 

I should add that all of this self evaluation is starting to make me fear being manipulative. I should also state that I don’t feel like a “fake” person––what I’m saying is genuine, but the scale is far different. The perspective is auto-corrected.

I watched a lot of people this month, all from private concerts to Y2K parties. I am realizing more often that there really isn’t one way to win it. Which, of course, would be awful, but at least it would be simple. Maybe it’s the obstacle of it not being simple that the true course leads us up to. 

Where next? Duke, in less than a month. To Small Town Records, to Hoof N’ Horn, to Giles, to Freedom and Moral Obligation––all vernacular that I hope will become well integrated into my lexicon. I’ve thought about keeping this blog as a time capsule of this year, but I have liked the way it’s made me think. 

I want to keep this blog because I’ve loved watching myself growing up. I’ve mentioned this befreo, but in the form of notebooks, of songs, of pictures, of finstas. But I the hope is that this record keeping might amount to something. The risk of making that tethered to the world feels real––it’s a record of my evolution for each to judge, though few actually stumble upon it. It feels intimate. It feels like you’re somehow supposed to be reading this.

And in a shocking turn of events, the accountability results. I like that process––being vulnerable enough to the people who are even remotely interested. The idea that even a few people are interested in watching a process that they are a part of, and a process that they are quite familiar with: asking why.

So, with that being said, here’s a cheers to you: to the people who, for some reason, found themselves clicking a link from an email or an instagram story, who are ready to watch themselves grow.

Here’s to another year of public record keeping; another year of trying to find the best balance of life.

Best,

Alex

item.title: AUGUST: CONTRADICTION
item.content:encoded:
Before I get into the nitty-gritty of this month, I'd like to point out a mistake that I made last month. A friend of mine read over the July post and noticed that I directly contradicted myself.

I have come close to perfecting the art of a one-on-one interaction; I'm able to both send and receive cues to make sure that each person is on the same page, and as such, I feel confident in my ability to socialize. However, the instant that one-on-one becomes a group of people, I lose my footing—I usually talk more to myself than other people in those instances.

In a group of eight, I can tell what my place is, where my comedic timing should be, and what I should be driving in the conversation. The doors feel open, inviting, and almost playful––I can play bits with some in the conversation while peaking the interests of others. 

I should also add to this juxtaposition that there isn't much scarier in the world than someone saying, "oh, I read your blog post." Part of it is the disparity between my perception and performance, but I've tied most fears to failure and her cousins, of which there are many. 

I don't think this was just a mistake on the page, and in a short period of retrospect, the words "perfecting" and "one-on-one interaction" are a unique and boisterous pair. I have to work in hyperbole, or else this would be mundane note-taking. To sum it up, I don’t think I’ve come close to understanding either.

I have now been at Duke for a week, and I, as many others are, am quite overwhelmed––not only by the number of opportunities I already feel like I'm missing out on, but the social element can drown you. There are the typical college shenanigans of frat parties and "darties," which is a new word for me. Still, I think the most prevalent social catalyst is the frenzy for a group of people to text about lunch. I don't know if I've found my people yet––it's hard to judge that before I'm able to reflect on all of this with a bit of separation. I feel like a part of the rat race right now.

My classes start today, ranging from Chemistry to Philosophy, and I don't feel prepared, but I sure as hell will look it. Without that, the illusion falls. Duke is notoriously work hard, play hard, but I think a more accurate description is "work hard, tell no one." The students who claim they didn't even study might have spent around two hours reviewing––everyone is like each other, meaning that all of our bullshit is falling through.

I am at an inherent disadvantage because my interests are diverse. I can explore, but I also lose the confidence to commit to the business society or the symphony auditions. I saw it on the calendar and looked the other way. Is that because I don't want to be involved in the classical music scene on campus, or was I just too lazy to be proactive about my interests? 

I worry that I am not the "go-getter" that I so proudly was in high school. Still, I  don't feel any urgency to be that person yet—shockingly. I've started to believe the advice that freshman year should be about exploration and balance, not everything all at once. Maybe I burned out of everything all at once.

I'm not expecting to find my footing, but let me be clear. There is a distinction: knowing something will be uncertain does not make it certain, as I've established in previous months. I don't know who I want to be yet, which most would reply with "yourself," which brings me back to the rabbit hole of last month and pretending. I can't even find a new question to obsess over when my answers are references to previous unanswerables. 

What other unanswerables await? How can I make sure that this chemistry class doesn't make or break me? It's Chem 101, which countless other first-year students from all around the world have completed, but my takeaways and commitment to the course will change my path at Duke. Taking it and enjoying it (sort of?) would mean opening the door to inorganic and organic, leading to medical school; taking it and wanting it to be over would lead to the neuroscience major; taking it and hating the essence of the study would mean abandoning STEM entirely. There will always be someone better.

It's now far later in the month, and I have a few more things to comment on. I have been accepted into the Pitchforks, Duke's oldest all-male a cappella group-–I immediately felt relief. They welcomed me into what already feels like a make-shift family, and I don't think I realized how much I missed making music with others. (It also doesn't hurt that I'm joined by two of my PEADs alumni).

I have already alleviated most of my fears about performance; it's clear that I'm still the tryhard that I always have been. I am overwhelmed by the pure optionality that I have access to––I don't think I fully grasped how large 15,000 is. As I've mentioned in this series before, humans are notoriously bad at predicting the future and seeing out of our perspective. That sure won't stop us from trying.

All of my classes have been better than I expected: exploring topics from Plato's Republic and social contract, looking at how economic principles fail when assessing our market from a sociology perspective, translating dear inventus Catullus, maddened by passion, and learning about enthalpy and calorimetry. Classes range in size, but I have only felt anticipation before each one.

One prediction that seems to have come true is my tendency to try and prove myself to others. Of course, Imposter syndrome doesn't leave with willpower, but it certainly shouldn't be a focus for me. 

I've started taking subjects more seriously––to be clear, this could be freshman ambition, but I've been intentionally translating much slower and reviewing concepts before and after chemistry lectures. I've realized that I don't hate school, as I claimed to when I was much younger. I hate feeling frustrated, and that feeling only arrives when there's dissonance between what I could be doing and what I'm doing. I feel in control again. I think direction is pulling me left and right.

I am trying to embrace being the fool on campus, and I've succeeded in making a fool of myself. Such examples include walking into the wrong classroom and calling Nicola Ultra "MK Ultra." That one is endlessly embarrassing because it showcases not only my lack of social fluency but also an odd amount of knowledge of a CIA torture study, possibly displaying… masochism?

Stress has hit close to home. But it has also reminded me that I am a force with which to be reckoned. Even when I stumble over my words in a class discussion, I know that I will start the reading for the class next week on the bus ride following. 

As far as who I would like to be, I think it would be presumptuous to try and decide that. Right now, I want to find equilibrium and revel in the routine that I have been craving for so long.

With that being said, here is to new beginnings and another year of pause.

Best,

Alex

item.title: SEPTEMBER: ROUTINE
item.content:encoded:
September has been a whirlwind of a month, but hopefully, I can bring myself to summarize and reflect on the majority of happenings—at least the ones that seem most potent.

In the past few weeks, I’ve: auditioned for American Idol, experienced a wide variety of college social activities, started art history research on Duke’s image database of Medieval Sicily, had dinner with a neuroscience professor, been to a Duke football game, struggled through a few chemistry labs and did decently on the midterm (alleviating August’s worry), sang more than I have far too long, learned Telemann’s Sonata in A Minor for oboe, took a trip to Camden, SC with Pitchforks (a cappella), and been hired as an audio engineer for Small Town Records (Duke’s record label). To be brief, I’ve been working hard on projects and with people that I care about—I couldn’t be happier.

There are moments that I try to take a step back and smell the roses, but just like at Exeter, time moves differently here; a week feels like a month. So while I want to lean back and enjoy fall break, which starts in approximately three hours, I can’t stop focusing on the two papers and the take-home exam looming on the other side. I’ve realized that being ahead of my work makes little difference in how I see the job—it still seems overbearing.

The biggest challenge I’ve faced so far is intrapersonal meddling with the interpersonal. I seem to get in my head—I always have and always will—but that doesn’t feel like a satisfying resolution. I think many of my overthinking tendencies will slow down as I continue to get more comfortable with my people here. I’m still hesitant to call them my people, not because of anything they have done proactively, but I have difficulty understanding if I’m myself around them. I’ve written about self-deceit before on this blog, but again, it’s hard to be reflective when I’m living it.

I find myself giving lots of advice to many who have a more challenging time adjusting to college than I am. That’s not to say that everything has been peachy, but I’m assuredly getting closer to a comfortable equilibrium. I would probably be happier if I took a bit more of my advice, only to give back what others have given to you, to take things at face value, to lean into being the fool. It’s much easier to tell others what to do.

I need to decide on classes soon, which means I also need to determine more direction in my academic path. I’m trying not to panic; I’m trying to believe that I have time to decide.

I have loved my classes. We’re finishing up Catullus and starting Tibullus in Latin, and the discussions about the Roman ideal of masculinity have permeated my daily life analysis. I’m writing about self-interested morality for my Freedom and Obligation class and a counterargument to Robert Nozick’s Anarchy, State, and Utopia for my Freedom of the market class. Chemistry lulls in the background—that’s not to say that I’m not captivated by the concepts, but the class size makes it feel quite dystopian.

I’ll keep it brief this month—I think much of the reflection for this month will come after.

With the best of luck,

Alex

item.title: OCTOBER: ARCHETYPE
item.content:encoded:
A brief summary to start us off, as it usually goes:

I should begin with the fall break that I was feeling so anxious about at the time of my last post. I was on an uphill climb at that point; I had two essays and a critical analysis ahead of me. I've started to notice that benchmarks like that tend to define the period that I'm in and the space that surrounds the milestone. I'm trying to separate myself from that mentality by spreading assessments into smaller assignments, but that is proving harder in practice than theory.

Fall break itself was quite an enjoyable experience: I was able to bond with many of the members of Pitchforks without the context of Duke looming over our shoulders. I didn't feel rushed for the first time this academic year, and that's a feeling that I'm trying to incorporate more into my routine (of course, the nature of relaxation or ease being scheduled into a routine seems a bit too oxymoronic). I look up to a lot of the group's older members: how they model a balance, how they prioritize, and how they all are honest in their interpersonal interactions. I missed being around people who see larger than college, an attribute that I have not seen prominently displayed since characters from my gap year. They know who they are—this is water.

I learned more traditional beach activities, such as the infamous game of Spikeball. Still, I also watched friends play melodica at the beach during the sunset, heard stories from home while swinging on a hammock, and brushed up on my Catan skills. While I can't say that I'm entirely comfortable to "be myself" (only due to semantics and the issue of defining such terms), I can say that I feel like Pitchforks is my backbone; a backbone for which I lean on often and am quite grateful for. We donned our velvet blazers, and I cannot express the relief I felt when it fit, despite being outside the size offerings.

I read two books this month: Kafka on the Shore by Haruki Murakami and Cat's Cradle by Kurt Vonnegut. Both offered refreshing literary images that I hadn't seen in English in quite a long time. Somehow the myth of a runaway is a story that fell into rhythm with my few weeks with it; I missed the feeling of wanting to feel like the character you're reading about.

I should mention that I have continued to take oboe lessons this semester, which has been a mixed bag of emotions for me. I have always had a complicated relationship with the instrument, as it brings out my inner perfectionist and critic. I'm learning Telemann's Sonata in A Minor, and while the piece is not complex by traditional means, it has been my first real piece of repertoire since March 2020. Oboe wasn't something that I felt motivated to keep up within the midst of the pandemic, but it's something that I found myself missing after I left it behind.

My instructor, who has been nothing but supportive as I relearn scales, has noticed trends that quickly lead to psychoanalysis: stopping a phrase because of a small mistake, having many false starts, moving the stand closer each time I make a mistake (implying that it's a matter of vision as opposed to skill). These tiny ticks signal more immense insecurity in my playing, which leads to frustration, which certainly does not have positive physiological impacts on the dynamic breathing needed for such an instrument. It's a good metric of my perfectionism: if I push myself too far, it makes the act of playing impossible. If, for example, I were to turn in a chemistry lab an hour late due to a break in routine, that doesn't mean I should start drafting an email to explain my actions and drive myself into an emotional spiral over 0.3% of my grade. Still, instead, I should do what I can to turn in the lab incorrectly. All hypothetical, of course.

Another high-stress activity was my Small Towns Records audition. It's not that I genuinely expected to be signed, but the pressure of performing for a live audience for the first time in months was quite nerve-wracking. Small Town Records is Duke's record label, which seems far more like a fever dream than anything. Nevertheless, I brought out some old songs, sang for friends and strangers, and I'm still heavily involved in STR as an audio engineer. So I have much to look forward to in that regard––there's a sense of urgency that has been driving me to an odd request. STR also led me to Duke's Coffeehouse, which has brought me to corroborate work with comfort in a way that I've had a difficult time doing here so far. 

Working as an audio engineer feels like you're living in a nightmare that you're flying a plane without a pilot's license. While we're still in a highly shadow-based role, I realized that while I have taught myself the technical skills, I never needed to communicate them to other people. There's going to be a learning curve, but one that I am eager to fall down. I've become more comfortable asking questions––I'm only going to get out what I put in.

Part of that process, however, opened me back up to musical collaboration. October held, quite tenderly, a few of the most incredible memories I have yet of creating with others. I think the phenomenon of music as a language has been especially shocking for me since I speak it differently than they do. At first, that was discouraging––now it's enticing.

My research for the Kingdom of Sicily project also allows me to enter an odd headspace. I feel like I'm looking for something that so few have looked for; whether or not it is "worth" looking for is a far more complicated feeling to cope with. There have been a few exciting discoveries: churches that started as Roman temples, Greek graffiti that I could transliterate and translate, but the far more exciting mysteries are the ones that haven't been solved or those I have yet to understand. 

I have a terrible habit of babysitting, especially when I feel like I owe something to other people. Somehow, it must be that helping others out (even, mistakably, when they can take care of themselves) proves something about me. That's not to say that my motivation for it feels selfish, but I do know that it must be that way. I care that those around me feel comfortable for unmentioned reasons (praeterritio), which drives me to hyper-supplement support, in effect belittling them. Again, that's not to say that babysitting is a bad thing; it's just something I need to make sure that I'm not projecting onto other people. I feel proud of moments of notable caretaking, but I still find myself doubting how exactly I'm helping others. I don't trust my intentions, to be blunt. 

I think the flaw in caring for others is that I often do it with the image of my (short-term) sacrifice: leaving a room to clean a mess up, using my time as opposed to making others dedicate theirs, etc. I understand that these are "selfless," but it would be hard to affirm that it feels that way. Somehow I feel guilty when I'm not helping, but more of the lurking shadow of guilt when I'm the one to solve the problem. 

It's almost like I'm playing into an archetype that I don't know if I can truly embody. As aforementioned, these acts often come at my own expense with little acknowledgment, leaving me with nothing to hold myself upon. I think that came to a peak as the dynamics between friends changed, as I learned that there is a difference between taking care of people and fixing them. (It would be more apt to say learning, but a blog beckons conclusion.)

Propertius has been on my mind this month, and Sulpicia trails not far behind. I haven't felt this joy for the Classics in quite a long time, and while I find myself often stuttering over my translations in the classroom, I'm trying not to let that discourage my analysis. I've started writing songs about poets again––a process that always feels rejuvenating. I've been in an Ancient Greek reading group with a few students who have some prior Greek experience and a professor in the department here, and I've decided that I am embarking on the course in the spring. I'm weary, primarily because of my experience struggling through Greek my junior year of high school, but I'm hopeful. More than promising, though, I am more eager than ever to dive into the literature. I've only tipped my pedes into the pond of elegy while both Greek and Latin lyric remain. 

It was fun to see my family interact with my community here. I think they're reacting well to my routine here, but there are definitely things that I hope to work on. I think they know that as well. It's a matter of communication, but it is also who has ownership over that communication. I'm a driving force in this, but it was beautiful to see them be as goofy as I remember them in person. They saw the Pitchforks perform, but the real show was watching all parents interact after the concert. I think I could have written quite a few character studies about that night, ranging in the profession, geography, and life mentalities. I forget how heterogeneous impromptu conversations can be when not confined to campus; it reminded me of late nights at Wild Detective last year.

I learned, from Isaiah Berlin, different definitions of liberty; both positive and negative liberty seem to lead to despotism. I've read Rawls and a few other writers on the topic of free will, and I can't help but be brought back to J.P. Sartre's The Flies, a piece that echoes as I'm walking and a book that I am destined to read again before the year's close. Nevertheless, I will miss having this philosophy course within my repertoire, forcing me to slow down and feel comfortable with not understanding. 

I did have one moment of bravery in particular. At a Pitchforks event when the reigning Tenor 1 member was not present, I felt charismatic enough to substitute myself in for the part, and there was something quite magical about the adrenaline that I don't think I'll be able to articulate. It was the kind of affirmation that you don't crave until it's been served to you on a silver platter with your name engraved. That's not to say it's something I aim to pursue, but it was lovely as an odd gift. As a result, I've found myself leaning into social situations, a trend that is likely to continue into this month.

As expected, I have lost a bit of my furor from the beginning of the semester, but I think I'm near equilibrium; the problem is the persistent pendulum from week to week, or, even more horrid, day to day, that leads to discomfort. The classic case of the uncontrollable.

With that classic archetypal ending: until next time.

Best,

Alex Pieroni

item.title: NOVEMBER: IMPULSE
item.content:encoded:
I have been trying hard this month—I’ve concluded that the cliche “dark and gloomy” winter is justified in its redundant definition. In literature, the seasonal symbolism of winter usually refers to death, old age, loneliness, an ending, or grief. Winter can be tranquil (see Stopping by Woods On A Snowy Evening, Frost), but the cold is peaceful even in Frost’s poem because it matches the narrator’s primary emotion. Winter drives tranquility only when it fits the setting—an excellent justification for feeling sad in winter (either before winter began or as a result of it). 

I read the beginning of The Crossing by Cormac McCarthy so that you can blame my run-on sentences on him. It was a book that I loved and was ambitious to read initially, but after around 100 pages, it lost its zeal. I feel guilty for not finishing it, mainly because I didn’t read anything else this month. So perhaps it's worth a revisit, or I think I’m supposed to believe it’s worth a revisit.

This brings us to the central argument that I’ve been obsessed with this month. Bear with me as I spit some jargon out for the sake of the piece. In my philosophy class, we read “Freedom of the Will and the Concept of Reason” by H. Frankfurt. Frankfurt distinguishes between first and second-order desires to separate person and animal. First-order desires are in the form of “A wants to do X,” with A being the agent and X being the action, and second-order desires are in the form of “A wants to do X,” with A being the agent and X referring to a first-order desire. He defines a person as one with second-order desires, while the animal only has first-order desires.

I was sold on the argument at this point, as it seems like a relatively reliable distinction from the compatibilist standpoint. There are things we want to do, but they’re also things that we don’t think about wanting to do: the impulse to eat isn’t a choice I make, but rather the nature of being a surviving thing. The extent of a first-order desire can be debated, but I’ll limit them to physiological desires. While you want to eat out of a first-order desire, there are times you want to want to eat or times that you don’t want to want to eat. That is your second-order desire: you want to act upon the first-order desire.

There is one last distinction needed to implement this argument for my overall thesis of this month. While there are second-order desires, the more pressing definition is second-order volition: acting under the second-order desire. For example, a smoker who wants to smoke out of a physical impulse can be one of a few variations. The unwilling smoker doesn’t want to smoke, so he either smokes and is being controlled by first-order desires or doesn’t smoke and definitively has the choice. Essentially it’s the capacity to choose contrary to the first-order desire that defines freedom of volition. 

The far more troubling example is the willing smoker. The willing smoker wants to smoke, meaning that if he smokes, he is acting in line with his second-order and first-order desires. If he doesn’t smoke, then he has a different volition altogether. So when does the willing addict have freedom of intention? When he wants to want to smoke. The trouble with this is the ambiguity between first and second-order desires. How does the willing addict know that he is willing as opposed to overwhelmed by a first-order desire? (I don’t have a clear answer to this question yet, but I hopefully will by the time a related essay is due later this week.)

In short, winter overwhelmed me with first-order desires: to sleep, to hide, to record. I have met plenty of people, but I am more intrigued by the people I have already met. My friend, we’ll call him Dawn, brought up the worry flowchart to me. Essentially one evaluates whether or not there is a problem. If the answer is no, there is no need to worry. This is an excellent outline of filtering executive functioning, and I often get stuck at that step. I don’t usually find myself asking myself the question that way. It’s usually something more along the lines of “is there something I should be worried about?”. Nevertheless, I have a first-order desire to worry—it would be an understatement to call it an impulse. 

Regardless, if there is a problem, the following question is, “can I do something about it?” if there’s nothing within one’s power to do, no need to worry. I have qualms with this question—there are things that I worry about being able to worry about, relationships that I see from afar, and I want to act as some odd messenger man just at the chance of doing something about it. So I’m trying to record how I can do “something about it” without that examination manifesting in worry without substance. However, that becomes especially difficult when there is a lot of worry oneris (of burden, loosely). Someone said that I seem the person that would only hurt before they get hurt, and I am afraid to investigate that further—another time.

I found more space, spending time with friends throughout the day but also making intentional commitments to go to an odd dinner here and there. I am so impressed by the people around me constantly—I can’t tell if that emotion comes from goodwill or envy. Some people feel more separate, like someone I'm watching, and some I can't distinguish if I want to know out of necessity or curiosity. I want to improve my creative process and take lots of inspiration from others, but that new acknowledgment of knowledge (i.e., there is more to know than you know) feels more overwhelming than enthralling.

My readings of Kant this month have led to examinations of truth-telling and secret-keeping, and I don’t think there is a space more conducive for this intrigue than college. There are always three versions of a story here, but no individual has the whole thing. There are times to lie out of self-preservation, to benefit a relationship, to relieve tension. I am reluctant to admit that I have always been somewhat of a fibber, but it does have an assumption of higher knowledge; most people lie to “protect” others from information, assuming that they are somehow stronger or able to tolerate it. I think I can handle it, but am I the juror of others’ rational abilities? Again, uncertain. Lots of open questions this month.

So how am I? Well, for someone observing the dark winter driving a first-order desire to be warm, a half-read book, a hyper analysis of an anxiety chart, and significant doubts in my relationship with others, I’m doing just cheeky. I have spent a lot of nights just questioning how I end up in the situations that I do—indeed, the problem is not that everyone around me keeps messing up. Responsibility is not binary, especially when someone is liable for trust. But I’m finding it harder and harder to be patient in my relationships. My friend, one whom I’ve become quite close with as of late, said that each person one meets is a “little creature” to be studied. Semantics aside, I think I agree with that sentiment: I become close with people not because they are necessarily the model Kantian moralists, but because I understand their actions and the motivations behind them. If the logical progression makes sense, it’s not about fixing them or shaming them for some personal flaw. It’s a character study.

I’ve been evaluating many character studies this month, especially with people I have known practically my whole life. Seeing people grow over the years can be jarring—I’d be silly to dismiss that. On the other hand, I think it’s scary that someone could become uninterested in my character study or that I could write the conclusion of someone else’s. For as much as I analyze others, the only person I trust to analyze me is myself. Again, reliable source? Uncertain. I had a vivid moment while sleeping on a tile floor over Thanksgiving break after many long conversations. I felt such dissonance: between myself and the situation I found myself in, the stories juggled between ear and ear only to be forgotten altogether, and the communication that can’t be transmitted.

In short, it has been hard to both forgive and to be forgiven this month. I’m not sure if I have an onus to apologize for, but I can certainly say that someone can disapprove of you and be proud of you. Someone can be friends or family with you without enjoying you. And that is the scariest part of winter—the sun sets far too early, leaving all to get to know themselves too well. 

So here’s to self-determination to an extent, to patience while watching the characters write themselves, and to sleeping on floors.

Best,

Alex

item.title: DECEMBER: BURNOUT
item.content:encoded:
‘Tis the season for resolutions, reflections, and new beginnings. I’m back home for the end of the semester, spending time with family and trying not to feel too guilty about not moving as quickly.

I watched a video last night that talked about the “resistance” of procrastination: there’s the life we live, resistance, and the unlived life within. This concept comes from Steven Pressfield’s The War of Art, a book that I’ve recently added to my bookshelf on a long stack of books to read.

I think I feel imposter syndrome differently than I used to––before, I believed I wasn’t at a certain level or running the long-con of productive image that would eventually fall apart, but now it’s much more clear: the imposter syndrome is based on my internal image as opposed to come grand comparison game. I feel guilt for not being the projected image of myself.

So my new year’s resolutions are anti-resistance. There wil always be the tasks I don’t want to do, but I want to build this structure into routine to affirm myself that I am the person I am projecting.

What does that look like? My main goal is to follow a diligent morning routine without fail. No matter what obstacles lie ahead in the day, at the very least I can say that I started the day off correctly: making my bed, brewing coffee and slowing down, spending time on my hobbies, planning and morphing the day, etc. The actual routine spans an hour and a half, but it is daily time dedicated to refocus.

I’m also hoping to turn writing back into a habit. Over my gap year, I would take my old clunky keyboard everywhere––in the car, waiting for a table at a restaurant––and start writing. Now that school is a much larger aspect of my life, I have a harder time introducing my passions in smaller increments, adninstead I feel a surmounting guilt of not writing enough. The same applies for reading: I want to read intentionally and ambitiously.

We are always in control of our time, which means whatever we are doing is something we want to do. If I’m watching YouTube, I want to watch YouTube. But I don’t want to be someone who watches some absurd amount per week. I want to reclaim my time for myself and my creative endeavors. Outside of workflow and life vision resolutions, I want to make a real commitment to reply and be proactive about my relationships with others.

These reflections are easier to remark upon out of the context of campus. I left school in an odd spot––I took quite a brutal chemistry exam and believed that I sacrificed my grade in the class. This led to quite a terrible mental state. I found myself beating myself up for a result that I didn’t know yet. Of course, after a week of dreadful waiting, I didn’t throw anything away at all. My grade was exactly what I had hoped it would be before the exam, but that didn’t save me from the grief after the exam. It reminded me exactly how much this grade meant to me––not even because I care about being a perfect student, but I had put so much work into this course throughout the semester that I was terrified of throwing it away.

I’m going to return to moving slowly for the remainder of the break. But when I step foot on campus, it’s go time––for real.

Here’s to revving up the engine again.

Best,

Alex

item.title: JANUARY: REPEAT
item.content:encoded:
I'm pretty familiar with metathesis: switching a vowel and a consonant as a Texan. Words like prescription are pronounced prescription, and iron is pronounced iern. Usually, no one stops to correct me, and most times, these words are common enough that no one bats an eye. But there's quite a distinct difference between a slip of the tongue and the evolution of the word.

We don't think about language evolving daily, but we envision it on a large scale: languages trickling down from Sanskrit or Old English, leaving us with our expansive lexicon. I've been thinking a lot about this type of evolution––one that isn't seen but happens under the surface until you travel to a new part of the country and are stunned by just how subtle these changes are, leaving us to imagine what the macro scale must look like.

I've been off to a good start this semester. I've been leaning into a routine and challenging other cyclical elements, but I've found that when I set a habit like reading, I want to spend that time reading for pleasure instead of courses. For example, I'm often tempted to open a scholarly article when my 15-minute reading time begins, but I always find myself drained afterward.

My problem comes at the end of the day, where the night before, I hope to be as productive as possible the next day, so I schedule hours back to the back of work. As a result, I end each day constantly feeling like I missed something I should have gotten done, putting new meaning to what a 24-hour day means.

Out of both impulse and an urge to be responsible, I recently bought a fish named Bug. I wanted not just a routine for myself but something that immediately felt outside of my world of to-do lists. It's been nothing but a great experience, and this fish is spoiled. Friends come over, listen to the filter's flow, which almost emulates a zen garden, and are reminded of childhood pets and pet store trips. My family tends to avoid pet stores since every time we find ourselves in one; my father always finds a way to walk out with a new animal. Once, I went to a 10-year-old's birthday party, and they picked me up with a dog in hand. I love living in an animal-centered home, but I never realized what I missed when I moved away—a reminder that there is more than second-order desire.

I was cast as the narrator in Into the Woods, which I am equally excited and nervous about. I am thrilled to take on a role in the cast and be a part of Hoof 'n' Horn, but I worry that I've already got too much on my plate. Nevertheless, I am determined to give myself the best chance possible by operating on routine and proactive work rather than reactive work.

I want to take action on self-development more than ever: in the hyper-productive routine sense and inject mindfulness into each task.

I've been a part of rush for selective living groups at Duke, and I'm trying to keep a positive mindset; "no matter what happens," is a mentality that only goes so far. I want to think that I've done everything I can to give myself the best chances possible with genuine interest instead of some suck-up act. But it's hard to both self-evaluate and be evaluated in the same space.

At the end of the day, I'm around because people want me around; that's not up for me to decide. So it all comes back to control. And somehow, the act of cleaning a fish tank every Sunday leaves me with that illusion of control––I can't complain.

Here's to more evolution.

item.title: FEBRUARY: JENGA
item.content:encoded:
I think that feeling behind in life is the best thing that has ever happened. Every morning that I wake up feeling like there was more I could do, more time I could devote to meaningful work, there is an omnipresent drive to be better. That’s a version of success I can get with: raw and meaningful work, regardless of scale. I would much rather find myself than wait for someone else.

As expected, February didn’t last long. I cooked pasta and bread for friends, stressed over midterms, failed, sang, and faithfully celebrated Groundhog Day. I’ve been hard on myself, which brings me to my next topic.

For most of my productive career, I have focused on intentionally spending each hour of every day. Whether writing assignments or documentary-style YouTube videos, most hours of my day could be considered “productive” until about two hours before bed. I organize my tasks by how long they will take, block out the free time during the week, and play a Jenga game with all of my obligations.

But for as much as I wish to call myself a productivity master, I’m more of a junkie. There’s a crucial element that I only realized this week; my work isn’t dependent on my time at all. Most days, I’ll get to my 2 hours of focused work in the evening and want to collapse after working for four hours at 6 am. But, on the other hand, I’ve always worked better in the mornings––I don’t have the whole day to dread completing what needs to get done.

So I’m shifting my pedagogy a bit. Time is finite, but energy isn’t. I’ll keep you updated on how that works out, but I have a sinking feeling that time is bound to be challenging to part with.

I’ve also had a bit of a career and significant shift over the past month. I came into the fall of my first year planning on double majoring in Classical Languages and Neuroscience with a minor in Classical Archaeology on a pre-health track. However, over the past few weeks, it’s become clear that I’m not destined to become a doctor and subject myself to years of tests and evaluations that would cause more anxiety than needed.

It’s so hard to abandon the dream of medical school. But that’s precisely the problem: it’s a dream. Nothing is clear When I try and foresee my life as a surgeon, nothing is clear; I don’t know if I would be happy. Out of all of my career objectives, coworkers, salary, and fulfillment, the fulfillment is the predecessor. And a neuroscience major for a man who doesn’t want to do research or go to medical school is almost as useless as a Classical Languages degree.

I’m doing a big switch with that in mind, not without its anxieties. Duke offers an interdisciplinary major in Computer Science and Linguistics, which I hope to pursue. The only problem? I have no history or experience in computer science or linguistics.

For some reason, the unexplored territory doesn’t horrify me as much s it seems it should. And I like that. I like that I’m ready to fall on my face working through problem sets and trying to catch up.

Feeling behind pulls my feet ahead. Feeling fulfilled lifts my head up. Heading toward––it’s just the beginning.

Best,

Alex

item.title: MARCH: LACK OF RECKONING
item.content:encoded:
You’re in your twenties now. Do you have it figured out? Am I on the path right now?

There isn’t a big milestone of turning 20. No big party to attend or license to obtain, just texts to reply to and reckonings to, well, reckon with. Birthday cards from grandparents with 20 dollar bills, nods across campus, inquiries about what you’re doing to celebrate.

It is on your 20th birthday that you start to worry you’re growing out of birthdays. It’s when you’re 20 that you start to think about the adult decisions you have to make. It’s on your 20th birthday that you drop the ball one more time.

March was a month of exploration: of new art, new friends, new schemes, hard songs to write, bread making, book binding, reckonings. Not a month of documentation. Let’s save that for April.

Sometimes it’s easy to turn your life into a metaphor. Other months, it’s harder to get something on the page––to pull out of the mundane.

Until the next reckoning,

Alex

item.title: APRIL: STAGED
item.content:encoded:
For someone who performs more than average, it might be surprising that I hate performing. The getting ready and group mentality is always enjoyable, but the minute the pressure lands on me, there’s no one to call line, and you’re asked to give it your best shot in place of your best preparation? That is the peak of self-redundancy: critique the self and simultaneously improve upon it faster than the doubt can seep in.

I’m happy I ended up doing Hoof ‘n’ Horn this year––I met quite spectacular people, a few who goof and gaff, and many who were there to lend an ear when I believed I was begging for silence. 

I got through some tough classes this semester with flying colors. That outcome was often far from obvious: a 66 on my first neuroscience midterm helped me tie back my passions into a concise and marketable package. Now time to fill the weight behind the bullshit. 

I made lots of bread this semester: for parties, Pitchforks rehearsals, quarantine gifts, late night cravings. The recipe itself is not difficult, but rather time consuming, so it also ends up cooking up a bit of a crowd all waiting for the bread to come out of the oven to take that oh-so-precious bite. I like that feeling. 

I finished my book for Writing 101, Book. Art. Object., and I really love what I came up with. I’m hoping to continue collecting bits and pieces of future books when I’m in Italy this summer. I like keeping fragments of artistry in my life––feels a little less cookie cutter. 

Played lots of board games. Odd elevator rides. New families. Sore arms and legs. And tough goodbyes.

As I’m writing this, I’m looking forward to a fun beach week with some of the people I love most in this world. But I’m also having a hard time passing the time. When it’s fleeting, decisions can be made on a whim, decisions without structure––but when it lulls? You lose the beauty of time running faster than you can catch it.

I’m off to pack. Overall, freshman year left me hopeful and resentful: both of past and present, then and now, and whatever else may arrive in an oddly shaped package on the bus. 

Until next,

Alex

item.title: MAY: PRESENT
item.content:encoded:
May was a whirlwind, moving from weeks saying my farewells to my closest friends to finding an odd routine back at home and preparing to head to Italy for three months. 

Beach week, a tradition at Duke, was the first time I felt truly present in the past few months. We cooked and shared quite a few laughs, reminisced on a cinematic year, and took our time as each day passed. In high school, it took me two years to really find my people. I’m grateful that process was much faster at Duke. I felt at home.

I’m happy that the pandemic brought me the gift of cooking. There’s nothing quite like cooking a meal for the ones you love. The famous ‘Alex Bread’ has found its own plague at Duke, with the opportunity to turn it into a money-making machine. It’ll come in time. At home, I tackled a 3-day croissant recipe for the first time. And the focaccia plus cheese combo (more commonly known as pizza)? It was a hit, to say the least.

When I left campus, I was met with familiar scenery––late nights catching up with parents, the all too alluring endless scroll, and monotonous but somehow comforting feed of content. There’s a dissonance in coming home: it’s almost like reintroducing yourself. I took my time, acknowledging that it was a time of rest, but it’s so hard for me to shake off the feeling of guilt when doing ‘nothing’. I pushed that into songwriting. I don’t write in the same way at home as I do at school. In my dorm, I pick up my guitar when I have to––when there’s not enough to be said but too much to be sung. I pushed myself to get out of the door: to coffeeshops, rock climbing gyms, old streets. I’m reckoning with a new identity. A year ago, I was almost certain I would be a doctor. Now? I am once again seduced by the art of archaeology.

I’ll write more as I head into summer, but for now, I rest easy with contentment, eagerly awaiting the next chapter of momentum.

Best,

Alex

item.title: JUNE: PAST
item.content:encoded:
Nothing makes me feel more alive than digging. The days are long––I start by dragging myself out of bed at around 5:30 am, and we usually don't get home until around 6:00 pm. That usually means I tend to mentally collapse the minute we get back, but that doesn't mean there isn't dinner to prepare and the next day to set up for. The work is incredible––more than ever, I feel like I am starting to understand the theory behind the archaeology I am doing. The site I am at, Vulci, uses the single context system, a stratigraphy method meant to be the opposite of the old archaeology of plunderers. Each layer is documented meticulously with patience and astute observation from a whole team, experts and novices. I feel like my opinion is sought after, although I am one of the youngest on the site.

Digging makes me feel very present. The only thing to worry about is the unit before you, trying to understand the activities that brought about that pile of dirt. It has also helped me think about the ancients differently. It wasn't just the Etruscans, the Romans, then the medieval: they reused and adapted elements and foundations of old cultures as we still do today. I've started to think about the foundations I have built and what will remain of my spoliation and dirt. It feels good to feel the texture of my hands, eroding them with hidden trash.

Not only am I digging, but Vulci is also unique because of the small team. That means that everyone does a bit of everything, from the analysis and pottery washing to the documentation and stratigraphy matrices. As a result, I've had to internalize what I learned in Orvieto in 2019: it's not a fundamental mistake if you learn from it. More in archaeology than in any other field, the only way to learn is to ask questions from people worldwide who have studied more than you and always feel like a bit of a rookie.

Our field director gave me a trowel and told me that because I was so bravo––her English is improving every day, but my Italian is coming along much more slowly––she wanted me to keep one of the site trowels. The trowel is miles ahead of the one that I got on a whim when I believed archaeology would be a word to describe an odd summer of high school. Each day I'm here, it becomes clearer that to dismiss it so blissfully would be tragic. I can't let this passion go. I've followed passion my whole life, even when it was unheard of for a twelve-year-old kid to self-produce an albeit less than mediocre album. But I did it regardless.

I used to call myself a perfectionist. I don't think that's accurate any longer. I'm not a perfectionist but a go-getter: I'm a master at overloading my plate because I get excited at the swarth of open doors and possible roads. I want to learn, but I also have difficulty forgiving myself when I don't get something right the first time. I work quickly, with lots of shitty first drafts, and I find it hard to find the patience to revise. But after enough first tries, after enough fragments and quick bursts of inspiration, I will often gather the strength to reset and take a step back. It isn't quite a revision, and it's far from perfectionism: it's ambition. I admit that ambition is a blessing and a curse. I often find myself overloaded with projects in which I no longer see life, but I would be remiss to dismiss the joy that ambition has brought me. When I have many doors still open in front of me, and one of them fits? It somehow feels like it was on purpose the whole time.

Over the past few weeks, I've focused on pottery more and more. Studying ceramics never crossed my mind, but I love the details and patience that the process requires: to wash, sort, diagnose, and inventory. While archaeology often leads us to the most apparent remnants of ancient life, such as the decadent temples, mausoleums, and tombs of the aristocrats, pottery was universal throughout most social classes. While some were more valuable than others, you can hold a shard in your hand and think of how many lives it has lived––as cookware, canteens for wine, or small containers for perfume.

I have another three weeks here before I explore some other parts of Italy and return home. Here's to more adventures and more time in the trenches.

Best,

Alex

item.title: JULY: TRANQUILITY
item.content:encoded:
First and foremost: this marks the end of Year Two and the beginning of Year Three of the Year of Pause project. I’m quite proud of the work that I have produced over the past two years, and I can’t wait to continue onto Year Three. Writing has always served as a way for me to knock on my own door, slow down, check in, evaluate, consider, and live intentionally––that’s how the project started, and that’s how I hope for it to continue.

The last few weeks of the dig were demanding but rewarding; I met more people despite an ever-decreasing language barrier, thanks to my daily practice in Italian. I asked more specific and educated questions about the structure of the excavation and historical context and cooked some more good food. I enjoyed my time at Vulci and hope to return in not too long, even if it’s only for a few weeks.

I’ve continued my enthusiasm and curiosity for learning, and I believe it’s at an all-time peak. Nothing makes you feel the perfect kind of stupid like being immersed into an entirely different culture and discipline; my understanding of what archaeology means––documentation for the sake of preservation––has expanded past a methodology. But, of course, that would not have been possible without the excellent team at Vulci, who laughed and taught me as I blurt out jumbled Italian; we, lovingly, say that I speak in Esperanto. And for seven weeks of learning? I’ll take anything that isn’t “stupid American.”

There is one person that I’d like to highlight that I didn’t get the chance to last month. Alessandra, whom I can now call a dear friend, ‘la regina,’ and the best Italian mother that I could ask for, immersed me in not only the understanding of ceramics and materials but also educated me about Italian culture, nuances, and quite a few life philosophies that I will continue to learn from for quite some time. She gave me her utmost attention, even when it didn’t seem feasible: when we were behind on inventory, that didn’t stop her from answering my excessive questions about impasto rosso-bruno, and she took extra care towards the end of the excavation that I understood not only what I was doing, but also why I was doing it: the uses, the chronology, etc. She is only one example of a person I met this summer who was invested in my education simply because I was enthusiastic about it.

Laura and Enrico, our field directors, continued to explain over and over which layer covered which, the minuscule differences between the red-brown and the brown layer, the friable and the compact, and they seemed to enjoy seeing the look on my face when I finally understood, which allowed me to dig with never-before-seen confidence. Their patience gave me more knowledge than any textbook could. Moreover, because I was learning from them daily, it opened a new door of professionalism and friendship that I hope to maintain over many years. I watched and tried to understand their Italian conversations about the relationships between layers and why some decisions would be riskier than others. Still, I learned the most from their opened-mindedness: it wasn’t that one person was right, but it was the earth that told the truth.

And I would be remiss not to mention Dylan and Andrew, the fellow Americans who lived with me in Via Tre Cancelli, a quaint home of peace and lots of Best Brau. I watched Andrew study for his Ph.D. archaeology exam, and as he learned by teaching, I learned by being taught. I got to see another lens into the alluring world of academia. I learned many valuable lessons, ranging from ‘drink the juice, Shelby’ to ‘don’t polish a cannonball,’ but most of all, I learned from getting to know them, their stories, and their why’s of archaeology. It’s a pretty crazy thing to do when you think about it––but the crazy people here are the ones I found the most solace in.

Of course, others along the way opened my eyes to another world, such as Rebecca and Margherita, with whom I explored Cerveteri and discussed the classic philosophical problems plaguing us in our twenties. Their patience and willingness to teach me, as with everyone in the dig, made Vulci a bit homey for me. In addition, their persistence in the site, sieve, lab, and late nights at the Birreria encouraged me to take my time.

After seven weeks of excavating, I didn’t expect a grand revelation, but I hoped to have a few more answers about where I saw myself in the next few years. I am somewhat proud that I don’t have the expected answers. Nevertheless, I am pleased to say that I hope to see myself back in Italy soon, and I realize I have more time than I anticipated.

I enjoyed spending the week alone in Florence, watching Americans stumble about, Italians give odd looks, the many faces that almost look like someone I know, and wandering through side streets searching for the perfect notebook. This time in Florence was an actual vacation: time spent alone dedicated to recharging and exploring on my own accord. One night stands out: as I was returning home to my hotel, I heard a singer singing Chris Stapleton, and it was only natural that I entered, ordered a cocktail, and listened to this Italian sing everything from Johnny Cash to Cat Stevens. While there, I met an American couple who was in Italy for their first wedding anniversary. They asked me about my travels, and I told them about my summer work, ranging from studying materials to implementing GIS and digital archaeology methods. Indeed, my favorite part was when they asked my age––they were immediately taken aback and began their sentences with “I wish…” and “if only…”. It’s good to take a step back through their eyes to re-realize just how lucky I am.

Inevitably, some scheduling adjustments to my plans in the fall regarding coursework have occurred, thrusting me into yet another spiral of doubt about my computer science experience or lack thereof. I’m trying to work through some online courses before I return, but it wasn’t sustainable during the excavation, which has sent me wildly off track. I also worry that when the time comes that I have the tools to create something, it won’t be truly original in a way that I will be satisfied with. 

I’m excited to see my family in a week or so as I finish the final leg of this trip. But I’m also excited to come home and return to a different sense of tranquility, to see old friends in New York, and of course, to return to my routine-oriented life back at school.

So here’s to diving headfirst into learning, the all-too-familiar impostor syndrome, and unbridled enthusiasm for failure. 

Until next,

Alex
